body:
You have learned to trust your gut - nothing wrong with that.  However, some of your complaints *could be* viewed as creating drama.  I don't thinks so, because I understand why you are so hyper-sensitive to admin issues, after what you put up with in Reddit, I can't blame you.

All I can say, is lay low maybe, and keep trusting your gut.

body:
We don't hate you. But you did spend a huge chunk of time the other day bitching at another admin for engaging in perfectly acceptable, industry standard design review feedback process.

When you dedicate lots of time and effort to complain about things that aren't problems, it undermines your credibility for everything else. Bear that in mind as you seek to grow and develop relationships moving forward.

body: I checked through the focus group thread where kek tried to answer a lot of your questions. It seemed to me like you are rather adamant in how ruqqus should be developed so you don't feel left out. Could it be that your prior experiences and, possibly, your personality traits make you a bit sensitive to how others act? Some of your responses in said thread were very nitpicky and the answers you got didn't seem to satisfy you despite being completely reasonable. In the end there is little else to do than just letting things go and stop a meaningless conversation that leads nowhere and in some ways remind you of a discussion in bad faith. I don't mean you any harm by writing this. I don't think you're a bad person.

post.title: Why do the admins hate me?

body:
I've been banned by the discord twice - perma banned now. Do I think that @captainmeta4 hates me? No. Hate is a very powerful word. Do I think he dislikes me to a degree? Sure. 

Why bother wasting your mental power on things that don't have any merit, such as this? This is quite far out there - and it's not like they've banned you from Ruqqus - infact quite the opposite, they responded to your post. 

When I was banned from Ruqqus discord, I had no assumption that the admins hated me, and I actually have a legitimate reason to think that. But I have enough emotional maturity to not bitch about it on this forum. Get a good reason to think this before you actually say it.  

Is it unfortunate that I got banned? Sure. Do I care enough? No. You need to evaluate what makes you even think this way in the first place. The reasons you listed are not good enough.

body:
I was only asking questions. I complain about certain things because I want to make Ruqqus better, I don't mean to offend you or your efforts here. You do great work. If I didn't care about Ruqqus I wouldn't bother to criticize anything.

You're right that I'm miffed now. I can see why that might make you more weary of me *now*. However, I didn't complain at all until about a month ago, as I saw no issues yet, but you guys seemed to be avoiding me before then too. So what was it then, before my complaints started, that made you not want me around, is what I'm asking. I legitimately want to know this so I can improve in the future, as it's very hard to see your own faults. As of now I'm clueless and stuck in an endless loop.

body:
Nothing, I don't think I'm special at all. What I don't like is how some other people seem to be special, and do have more access and more control than the rest of us (other than the admins ofc). I'm complaining about the very thing you think I want.

I made +bugs since I had nothing else to do, I thought it'd be convenient for the admins. But  yesterday when I told them about it they started telling people to post it in the feature suggestions places instead. That doesn't make a whole lot of sense, which makes me feel like they're just making excuses to avoid interacting with me.

This started long before I made any complaints about it, as they gave a bunch of users roles in the site *before* it began annoying me, and back then too they left me out (the users they chose didn't, just the admins). Apparently they talk to some people in DMs and on Zoom calls even. If there's a reason for why they avoided me I understand, I just want to know why so I can change my behavior in the future. I know my excessive complaining now doesn't help me but that couldn't have been the reason back then as I hadn't done any yet.

body:
> I legitimately want to know this so I can improve in the future, as it's very hard to see your own faults

This is a good attitude and a very good point - just make sure you legitimately can take criticism without flaring up.

I know, because this is a fault of mine.  I have to *always* take a step back before I post or comment because I know that I tend to respond quickly with emotion.  It's a lot better when I take at least a few minutes to ask myself "Am I going to be ok with the response to this?" If I can't, I'm not ready for that discussion.

I don't know, I think your heart is in the right place, and we do need users who keep tabs because it's sort of like a civilian review board for the site.  Keeps little issues from, becoming big issues.  

"Pick your battles" is probably the best advice.

body:
> Hate is a very powerful word. Do I think he dislikes me to a degree? Sure.

This is true in my case as well, but with the way the word hate is thrown around these days I didn't think about it.

I'm only bitching about it here because I have no other way of finding out what I'm doing wrong. How else am I supposed to figure out why they've always been weary of me (before I began complaining even) if I don't ask? Why have they disliked me from the beginning? And how do I change or improve if I don't know what it is about me that's wrong?

This has been a recurring theme for me so far, and ruqqus is far from the only case of it (the only exception I can think of is that I was welcomed onto /r/WatchRedditDie's mod team and am respected by them). So yes, the problem is probably with me. I just want to know what that problem is so I can fix it. I know it's not only the complaining, because I'm avoided *before* I make any complaints, which results in more complaints. And it's even more frustrating when everyone who would know doesn't want to tell me anything, almost as if they *want* it to be this way. Now I know that's not true of course, but that is how it *feels* after a while. I don't really know.

parent.body:
I've been banned by the discord twice - perma banned now. Do I think that @captainmeta4 hates me? No. Hate is a very powerful word. Do I think he dislikes me to a degree? Sure. 

Why bother wasting your mental power on things that don't have any merit, such as this? This is quite far out there - and it's not like they've banned you from Ruqqus - infact quite the opposite, they responded to your post. 

When I was banned from Ruqqus discord, I had no assumption that the admins hated me, and I actually have a legitimate reason to think that. But I have enough emotional maturity to not bitch about it on this forum. Get a good reason to think this before you actually say it.  

Is it unfortunate that I got banned? Sure. Do I care enough? No. You need to evaluate what makes you even think this way in the first place. The reasons you listed are not good enough.

author.bio:

body:
Yes, I'm *looking* for criticism. There's obviously something inherent about me that makes the admins weary of me, and I want to find out what that is. It can't be my complaints about the site, because I didn't start making any until recently, and they still avoided me even before, yet were eager to work with most of the other users of the site who were interested at the time, and I don't know why.

Ironically I feel like the admins on the other hand get very offended when I give any kind of negative feedback whatsoever. I usually just want to point something out that I think is flawed, so they can fix it, but they always take it as a personal attack on them. It's quite the opposite, if I hated them or the website I wouldn't care about trying to improve it, but I guess they just think anything I say is automatically in bad faith. This isn't the (only) reason why they don't like me however, as I didn't do this until recently, and they avoided me before too. They were weary of me right from the start and I want to figure out why.

parent.body:
> Hate is a very powerful word. Do I think he dislikes me to a degree? Sure.

This is true in my case as well, but with the way the word hate is thrown around these days I didn't think about it.

I'm only bitching about it here because I have no other way of finding out what I'm doing wrong. How else am I supposed to figure out why they've always been weary of me (before I began complaining even) if I don't ask? Why have they disliked me from the beginning? And how do I change or improve if I don't know what it is about me that's wrong?

This has been a recurring theme for me so far, and ruqqus is far from the only case of it (the only exception I can think of is that I was welcomed onto /r/WatchRedditDie's mod team and am respected by them). So yes, the problem is probably with me. I just want to know what that problem is so I can fix it. I know it's not only the complaining, because I'm avoided *before* I make any complaints, which results in more complaints. And it's even more frustrating when everyone who would know doesn't want to tell me anything, almost as if they *want* it to be this way. Now I know that's not true of course, but that is how it *feels* after a while. I don't really know.

body:
That was *2 days ago*. I was only getting frustrated because the admins were being completely untransparent about it and refused to tell us anything. That's definitely concerning, even if they have good intentions with it, why does it have to be so secretive except to their favorite users, and why don't they like getting feedback from anyone else?

They've always disliked me however, and my current frustration is the result of that, not the cause. If it hadn't happened I would have no reason to be frustrated right now, unless I noticed someone else with the same issue. Maybe I just have really bad luck with this stuff.

body: While it does peeve me that the admins purposely excluded me after letting pretty much all my friends in, I'm a huge advocate of not having an IN group at all. I don't care how nice or constructive the people in it are, it's not how a free speech platform should be run, period. If you think I only started thinking that after this experience you're wrong. I have seen it in multiple other places and been against that kind of thing for years. I would not have advocated for it even if I were to be top dog. And I have created and moderated many larger subreddits in the past so I have plenty of experience supporting online forums such as this one. You don't know me.
